sub_topic: Finding the maximum flow in a network.
message_1:
A company has a network of pipes transporting water from a source to a storage tank. The diagram of the network is shown below:

![Graph Theory](https://i.imgur.com/n5Jmo2f.png)

Each pipe has a capacity in liters per minute, as shown in the following table:

| Pipe | Capacity (l/min) |
|------|-------------|
| 1->2 | 30 |
| 1->3 | 20 |
| 2->3 | 20 |
| 2->4 | 10 |
| 3->4 | 30 |
| 3->5 | 20 |
| 4->6 | 10 |
| 5->6 | 20 |

What is the maximum flow in liters per minute that can be transported from source 1 to the storage tank 6?
message_2:
To find the maximum flow in the network, we can use the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm. We will find augmenting paths and calculate the bottleneck capacity of each path. The sum of the bottleneck capacities will give us the maximum flow.

1. Start with an initial flow of 0.
2. Find an augmenting path from source 1 to storage tank 6.

First augmenting path: 1 -> 2 -> 4 -> 6
Bottleneck capacity: min(30, 10, 10) = 10

Update the capacities:
| Pipe | Capacity (l/min) |
|------|-------------|
| 1->2 | 20 |
| 1->3 | 20 |
| 2->3 | 20 |
| 2->4 | 0  |
| 3->4 | 30 |
| 3->5 | 20 |
| 4->6 | 0  |
| 5->6 | 20 |

Second augmenting path: 1 -> 3 -> 5 -> 6
Bottleneck capacity: min(20, 20, 20) = 20

Update the capacities:
| Pipe | Capacity (l/min) |
|------|-------------|
| 1->2 | 20 |
| 1->3 | 0  |
| 2->3 | 20 |
| 2->4 | 0  |
| 3->4 | 30 |
| 3->5 | 0  |
| 4->6 | 0  |
| 5->6 | 0  |

Third augmenting path: 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 6
Bottleneck capacity: min(20, 20, 30, 10) = 10

Update the capacities:
| Pipe | Capacity (l/min) |
|------|-------------|
| 1->2 | 10 |
| 1->3 | 0  |
| 2->3 | 10 |
| 2->4 | 0  |
| 3->4 | 20 |
| 3->5 | 0  |
| 4->6 | 0  |
| 5->6 | 0  |

No more augmenting paths can be found.

3. The maximum flow is the sum of the bottleneck capacities: 10 + 20 + 10 = 40 liters per minute.
